website_summaries.verdict: This exceedingly popular water filter is a remarkable choice for those wanting a supreme filtration system with a simple design.
pros: Filters up to 264 gallons of clean drinking water
Extremely simple design makes product easy for almost anyone to use
Protects users from nearly 100% of all bacteria and protozoa
cons: Difficult to suck water through straw
Customers wished the product came with a portable water pouch for on-the-go drinking

website_summaries.verdict: The LifeStraw has an indefinite shelf life and can be used to drink directly from a water source or, more conveniently, from a bottle filled from the source.
pros: Provides 264 gallons of safe drinking water without using chemicals or iodine
No shelf life, so it can be stored indefinitely even after use
Through suction, only clean water passes through LifeStraw's pores
Great for drinking from streams and lakes
Either drink directly from water source or fill up a bottle and drink from the bottle
cons: Takes a good bit of suction to get started and keep flowing
Be sure to submerge it so fibers can soak through before sucking

customer_reviews.title: Better alternatives on the market.
customer_reviews.text: Get a Sawyer-Mini. Seriously, I have used Both on camping trips. You need jaws of steel to suck water through a Lifestraw. With a Sawyer or other filters with pump/squeeze action, you won't rip out your fillings trying to get water. Also, you have to lie on the ground, whereas other filters come with collapsible pouches AND a straw if the pouch breaks. Before everyone down-votes this post, you Really need to watch actual videos of people who use these routinely. Everyone switches to a filter with a pump or squeeze method of filtration. Lifestraws are fantastic concept, but unfortunately, it is just too dang hard to use.
customer_reviews.author: SB

customer_reviews.title: Good luck
customer_reviews.text: Difficult to get meaningful amounts of water out of these and they seize up if you don’t clear the water shortly after each use. I’ve had two break in the last couple months and I didn’t even run a gallon through either one.
customer_reviews.author: Thomas

customer_reviews.title: Portability is nice but the fact that I dropped it from my ...
customer_reviews.text: Portability is nice but the fact that I dropped it from my mouth to the countertop while blowing water out of the tube and it stopped working is kinda ridiculous. There was no impact whatsoever, it was like 12 inches. If it can’t take any kind of an impact, and that’s dangerous to have as your only water source out in the woods. This bad review is for that fact alone.
customer_reviews.author: randu

customer_reviews.title: Combat proven, safe & extremely reliable filter!
customer_reviews.text: I've used these both in Iraq & Afghanistan. Works as advertised. Extremely reliable and genuinely safe to use filtration system. We now use it as a SOP to have one in everyone's ruck when we deploy! Semper Fi.
customer_reviews.author: American Patriot

customer_reviews.title: Get if you want be hippie.
customer_reviews.text: I drank out of a steam. I've become a hippie. Rejoice in my transformation.
customer_reviews.author: Garret JV

customer_reviews.title: Happy with this product already as I've used them in ...
customer_reviews.text: Got what we ordered. Happy with this product already as I've used them in Afghanistan when I was last deployed there
customer_reviews.author: David

customer_reviews.title: False Advertising
customer_reviews.text: I ordered 2 lifestraws that were advertised to filter 4000 liters or 1000 gallons. I received 2 lifestraws that only filter 1000 liters or 264 gallons. That's a big difference in the amount of water these will filter. False advertising.
customer_reviews.author: Fuzzy

customer_reviews.title: only filters 264 gallons which makes it really overpriced
customer_reviews.text: I purchased LifeStraw on October 4, 2018. I was disappointed upon receipt because the photo of the product packaging stated that Lifestraw filters up to 1000 gal. That is what I noticed when I placed the order. The product description shown beside that photo (which I did not notice before ordering) stated that it filters 792 gallons and the packaging on the actual product I received state that it filters 264 gallons. In addition, it seems there is no seller profile presently available. I will be more careful in the future because this product was definitely overpriced.
customer_reviews.author: CrystalStar

customer_reviews.title: Saved my life
customer_reviews.text: I am going to keep this one simple. Recently I got stranded in the back woods of the Adirondack Mountains. I had ran out of water earlier on the first day and used this until I was rescued on the morning of day three. THIS WORKS, this helped save my life. If you hike YOU NEED THIS PRODUCT.
customer_reviews.author: Richard Maxwell

customer_reviews.title: Impossible to Use
customer_reviews.text: We took these with us to a camping trip down at the gorge. There’s literally a river carving through most of it, so water is plentiful. These stupid things were impossible to use, it took 5+ minutes of teeth-fracturing sucking to get the flow started and once you got it started, the amount of water was minuscule. We followed the directions to a T, made sure to store them properly between use and saw no success in the entire 4 days we were trying to use them.
customer_reviews.author: Anna

customer_reviews.title: I went on a 12 mile hike and used it ...
customer_reviews.text: I went on a 12 mile hike and used it to drink out of a well that pumped water to a metal tub for horses to drink. There was moss at bottom of tub. Next day I got really sick with stomach cramps and diarrhea. I will boil water from now on before using this to remove taste. So i went to hospital with high fever and turned out I ate bad tacos. Filter is good.
customer_reviews.author: Carlos Carmona

customer_reviews.title: Didn’t work for me
customer_reviews.text: I heard these are incredible and live saving. Bought one for a trip “just in case”. I tried to use it after reading and following all the instructions, but could not drink water from it. Waaaaaaay to hard to suck through this straw. I had someone with bigger lungs give it a shot and nothing. I know it warns that it’s difficult to suck through, but we could not get it to work. Pretty disappointed
customer_reviews.author: Emma K

customer_reviews.title: NOT SAFE!! Made my girls extremely SICK!!
customer_reviews.text: DO NOT BUY OR LET YOUR KIDS USE!!!! I could I give this a zero I would. Two of our kids and two of their cousins got extremely sick after using the lifestraw at a stream. This was the number one gift my 10 year old wanted for Christmas and against my better judgment I bought it for her, knowing she’d drink natural water. 24 hours after drinking the water two of my girls for extremely sick and vomited all night long. No other siblings got sick only the ones who drank from the lifestraw. Sending this back and warning everyone that it’s NOT SAFE!!
customer_reviews.author: angelina lopez

customer_reviews.title: It's not 1000 gallons it says 256 gallons and 1000 liters
customer_reviews.text: I'm sure this product is great but its false advertising. The product says each straw can be used up to 1000gallons but it a type. It's actually 256 gallons and 1000 liters. So its sorta of lie to get people to purchase it for its use. So make sure your aware this only good for up to 256 gallons per straw..
customer_reviews.author: Andrew Richardson

customer_reviews.title: Life saver
customer_reviews.text: I keep one of these in my pack when hiking or going anywhere remote, as well as in my fishing tackle box on the lake. I’ve had to use it several times on the lake where otherwise I would have been severely dehydrated. Filters great. Personally, I only drink from PUR water filters as I’m a bodybuilder and regulate my diet to this point. This filter does just as well and it’s direct. It is quite difficult to bring the water to the straw but I don’t mind knowing that my water is pure. A child most likely couldn’t use it...but it could save your life.
customer_reviews.author: Zack Chavez

customer_reviews.title: Really
customer_reviews.text: Well, if you read derections it say soak in clean water to moisten filter. Question.? If i had clean water why would i need this?????? 😳😳😳😳
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: 1000 gallons
customer_reviews.text: These Lifestraws are as advertised and packaged together as a 3-pack. Each individual Straw is good for up to 1000 gallons of water. I haven't tried it yet, but got what I expected for a great price.
customer_reviews.author: Chad

customer_reviews.title: Took it with me on a trip to the 3rd ...
customer_reviews.text: Took it with me on a trip to the 3rd world slummy parts of Thailand and used it frequently in murky waters. Didn't die or fall deathly ill, so i guess it works. Only big grip is that it takes a considerable amount of time, patients, and physical exertion to draw water. Should only be used in dire emergencies, if there is a convenience store around selling bottled water, go for that instead.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Love our life straws
customer_reviews.text: We use them camping in areas of questionable water, & have found they work great. Also took them to India as emergency resource Its pretty compact, light weight & can be worn around the neck on its tether while day hiking. You do have to work within the limitations of the filter media, so do not expect to gulp down water as you drink thru them, but you can consistently sip thru then for quite a while before having to clear for a new drink. If you camp or hunt or travel to remote areas, take one, your life may depend on it.
customer_reviews.author: Minions Web

customer_reviews.title: LifeStraw Sucks ... literally and metaphorically!
customer_reviews.text: Oh man, I found it literally impossible to get a drop of water out of this straw. After one initial use after I bought it a couple of years ago, I had been carrying it in my backpack for emergencies. Yesterday I tried it "for fun" in a mountain stream to see if it would actually work in an emergency. I primed, I sucked until I almost fainted ... to my deepest disappointment, not one drop of water came out of this thing. It is completely and utterly useless. A total waste of time and money.
customer_reviews.author: BlüMüsiK

customer_reviews.title: One Star
customer_reviews.text: Stopped working after one use. Luckily I tried it out before my trip.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Stands up to dirty dish water
customer_reviews.text: As soon as I got this thing in the mail I went straight to the nastiest, most contaminated thing I could find. There just happened to be a sink full of soaking dishes that worked just fine. Couldnt taste a thing. I even spit some of the water out and it was nice and clear. Im going hiking soon and going to test it on some stagnant water when we find it, and I've given instructions to lower this rating down to 1 star if I die.
customer_reviews.author: nicholas marksberry

customer_reviews.title: Doesn't work properly.
customer_reviews.text: Never used a worse product than this. Mine was kept sealed since January and I just unpacked it for a backpacking trip to Washington. I honestly didn't know what to expect, but this product is absolutely awful. Couldn't get water through the straw without a herculean effort. Yes, I watched the youtube videos, yes I primed the straw. It's just not well made. Made me feel pretty bad for the people in third world countries and the soldiers on these reviews that claim this is a great product. Most people have just left a review and tossed it in a bug out bag. Get a platypus instead, it saved my life in the backcountry of WA.
customer_reviews.author: Dana Barciz

customer_reviews.title: So far no sickness haha and he said that the water flow through it is good.
customer_reviews.text: We took these to Costa Rica just in case we were not near any normal water source. We ended up not needing them bc Costa Rica has their water game on lockdown. We ended up giving them to a friend who is traveling around Thailand and Cambodia. He said he has used them while hiking in the mountains and they have worked very well. So far no sickness haha and he said that the water flow through it is good.
customer_reviews.author: Corey Breitling

customer_reviews.title: Must know of impending doom ( must be primed with potable water).
customer_reviews.text: No instructions on the straw itself. No one will be carrying that cheap piece of paper.
customer_reviews.author: Rudd 67

customer_reviews.title: Hard to draw from!
customer_reviews.text: Next to impossible to draw through. I tried, really really tried, but could only get a tiny bit of water. Now, don't get me wrong, they WORK. Attached pic is of me drinking from some pretty stagnant water, deep in country of Alaska.
customer_reviews.author: Noah

customer_reviews.title: Great for camping.
customer_reviews.text: It is everything you would expect from LifeStraw. It works exactly as they say. Instructions included for ease-of-use. Filters out most things you would prefer not to drink. This is my third LifeStraw. I do a lot of hiking and camping, and these have always been in my backpack. I have used these on some very funky water sources and have had no issues. However, taste variance has been present from time to time.
customer_reviews.author: Rob

customer_reviews.title: Worked like a charm
customer_reviews.text: Used it on a hike recently; tried different configurations as shown, with the drinking straight out of the river, and out of a wide-mouth bottle. The flow-rate through the LifeStraw is a little reminiscent of drinking a really thick milkshake, which is understandable considering the filter basically gets everything. When I filled up my nalgene with water from the stream, after walking a bit I could definitely see the sediment start to settle; even made sure to get some with the straw just to see. Worked like a charm, just need to remember to blow into it afterwards to clear out the straw.
customer_reviews.author: Kingston

customer_reviews.title: Won't Prime
customer_reviews.text: I bought three of these in 2013/14. Put them in my bug out bag. I pulled them out this week to test them...and they will not prime. I put them in clean water to prime the membrane and not luck. I sucked very hard and nothing. I must have a bad batch. Disappointed!!!
customer_reviews.author: buyer

customer_reviews.title: It's Okay.
customer_reviews.text: It's fine for what it is. Lightweight and very easy to use. However it only does 1000 gal of water and The Sawyer Mini does 100,000 gal of water. The Sawyer is also easier to use. I now use the Sawyer Mini with Sport Top Smart Water bottle and the Evernew Water Bladder. Some people use the Platypus bag but it doesn't fit as well and it's heavier.
customer_reviews.author: Paul Bonds

customer_reviews.title: Not Easy to Use - Get a Sawyer Mini
customer_reviews.text: I purchased 3 LifeStraws when they were on sale. Being an avid hiker and starting to dabble in backpacking, I'd heard of the LifeStraw millions of times and was excited to finally add one to my pack. I'll start by saying the LifeStraw is really for emergency use only. You literally either have to a) lay on your stomach at a water source and sip your brains out through the straw or b) fill up a cup and sip through that. Either way, the LifeStraw is not a great solution for getting clean water while hiking/backpacking. There is no possible way to use the LifeStraw to filter water into your Camelback/waterbottle/etc. Go get a Sawyer Squeeze instead!
customer_reviews.author: Callie

customer_reviews.title: A must have in your Emergency kit
customer_reviews.text: No questions, no doubt...A must have for your ‘bug-out’ bag. We have one each for our Emergengy ‘to go’ bags. Then one in our car emergency kit. Then we just ordered two for flight ‘carry-ons. We travel out of the United States a lot and have found it often difficult to find proper bottled water that we’re confident drinking. This way we feel ‘no real worries’ . We’ll still be cautious of course, but having the LifeStraw will certainly help!
customer_reviews.author: fieldmouse

customer_reviews.title: Works well for what it is.  Not as versatile as the Sawyer.
customer_reviews.text: As expected. Good for direct single-person drinking. Not good for filtering water for cooking or multi-person use, as it can only be used like a straw. I carry this as a backup on day hikes and when fly fishing. I use my Sawyer for smaller bulk filtration, and my Khatadin for larger camp jobs. Two stars off for the lack of versatility. Update: does not fit into a small-mouth Nalgene bottle. Gosh, you'd think the designers would have thought about making sure it works with all Nalgenes, given they are the most prolific outdoor water vessel. One more star off for designer oversight and for my disappointment.
customer_reviews.author: High Standards for Online Purchases

customer_reviews.title: gotta be very vewry good at sucking to make it work
customer_reviews.text: its so hard to use. I suck hard as I can only to get a drop. even my girl friend who is better at this type of thing had the same result
customer_reviews.author: thechosen1joe

customer_reviews.title: sturdy and doesn't take up much room
customer_reviews.text: I have six of these. one in each car and backpacks we take hiking. It is our safety measure in case we get lost on trails or while four wheeling. sturdy and doesn't take up much room.
customer_reviews.author: silver goose

customer_reviews.title: Does not work
customer_reviews.text: Based on recommendations, been buying and giving these to colleagues in developing countries. Eventually took one on a hike to test it out. Could not get one drop out of it. Came back home, reread and followed all the instructions (soak thoroughly, use warm water, etc ). Still could not suck more than a couple of drops out. Threw it away and am ashamed I gave some ot people who may really need it. Back to my regular filter pump...
customer_reviews.author: eric

customer_reviews.title: ... to the directions (several times) - and I can't suck or blow anything through the straw
customer_reviews.text: My unit doesn't work - I followed all of the instructions - primed it according to the directions (several times) - and I can't suck or blow anything through the straw. It seems like it is blocked or sealed on the inside.
customer_reviews.author: Joel Lang

customer_reviews.title: I tried to suck it all out
customer_reviews.text: I have no doubt that this straw can do everything it says in regards to filtration. However, I used it once on some ordinary water and could never seem to get all water out after. I tried to suck it all out, tried blowing as the direction say. I left both caps open, tried leaving it upside down... 2wks later and I could still get some water out by tapping it on my palm. I'd say get one and save it for when you really need it.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Consumer

customer_reviews.title: Filters Water like a champ!
customer_reviews.text: I bought this not really knowing what to expect. I was planning a trip that involved hiking and read many reviews recommending the product for even short day hikes (it never hurts to be prepared). I thought it to be an adventure. The life straw is very portable, can easily fit in a pack. We used it at the base of a waterfall and it filtered the water perfectly! Was cleaned as can be! PRO TIP: READ THE DIRECTIONS BEFORE YOU USE THIS. It gives useful tips for first use and what to do after use.
customer_reviews.author: Teresa

customer_reviews.title: Clogged up after one use.
customer_reviews.text: This item was purchased in Oct 19 but not used until July 20. All instructions were followed to rinse it and allowed to dry with orfices open, then attempted use of the Life Straw about two weeks later. No water could be sucked through the straw. When you depend on items like this to provide essential provision and it doesn't deliver, it's not only frustrating but completly disheartening since not having pure water could be life threatening.
customer_reviews.author: M. G. Caraway

customer_reviews.title: Recommended!
customer_reviews.text: Great for hiking we usually just use as a back up if we run out of water! It's amazing how clean the water taste through the straw! Great buy!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Impractical for use in survival situations because LifeStraw requires "safe" water to prime it before use.
customer_reviews.text: Useless in most any survival situation. The instructions, printed in almost unreadably small letters, read "upon first use or anytime the filter is dry, uncap both ends and stand it up in safe water (keeping mouthpiece out of water and dry) for 20 seconds to allow water to prime filter." If potable water is required just to prime the LifeStraw, it's very unlikely you'll have potable water on hand. After all, you're using the LifeStraw to filter contaminated water BECAUSE YOU'RE OUT OF WATER!!!
customer_reviews.author: JunkBMW

customer_reviews.title: Worth the purchase.
customer_reviews.text: It is Handy and a good idea and we bought a couple to put in our bug out bags and one to just try. My family all tried with some fresh water on a Day visit to the Zoar Valley Gorge near Buffalo, NY and we all drank water and no one got sick. I will say that you have to pull pretty hard on to get water through it. And then of course there's the whole nauseating reality of drinking lukewarm Lake water you have to get over but in an emergency situation or while camping if you lose water supply this could be a lifesaver so I definitely considered it worth the purchase.
customer_reviews.author: Courtney L. Rice

customer_reviews.title: tasted fine, was clear and I didn't get sick after ...
customer_reviews.text: I use this when hiking, Carrying water is heavy although I still do because some places don't have streams or anything. I have even used this in a muddy stream, tasted fine, was clear and I didn't get sick after drinking from a few questionable sources..lol The down side is that it takes a lot of suction to try to draw water through and I feel like it doesn't dry out properly after use. I worry about mold or things growing in it over time so I'll try to remember to update this after I've had it longer.
customer_reviews.author: softcell72

customer_reviews.title: Definitely get a few of these in case of emergency!
customer_reviews.text: a lot of people talk about stocking up on water and food in case of an emergency, and that's important! But having this in your car or bug-out bag is even more important! This heavy-duty filter can let you drink puddle or pond water safely if you are stranded or in an emergency situation. Highly recommended!
customer_reviews.author: LWoW

customer_reviews.title: Great Add to My Camping Kit
customer_reviews.text: Do a lot of backpacking and day hiking. Keep this in my pack to make sure I can always get clean water. Very lightweight and not too big tha I do not notice it in my pack. Used it one time to test it before I needed it in an emergency situation. Easy to use - put straw in water & drink. Easier than boiling and better tasting than purification tablets. Not great as a primary filtration system since you drink through this and then store it for long hikes but very useful as a backup.
customer_reviews.author: HathiTop Contributor: Camping

customer_reviews.title: Don't do it
customer_reviews.text: Wouldn't touch this product again.... can't even put a breath through it. Some reviews suggest that it may be glue in the back end. ....... I'f that is true, it's A LOT of glue, I even tried the suggested poking holes in the end. I am an an outdoorsy person... wish I had my money back.... will have a descriptive video on YouTube soon. Other, better options available. Wish it worked.. great concept, bad design... and im only in the Zion national park area.... what do I know...
customer_reviews.author: Anthony Frawley

customer_reviews.title: I'll sleep better with this around
customer_reviews.text: I'll sleep better with this around!. Yes, it does not filter chemical contamination. Of course you need to pre-filter the sediment and gross contaminants out first. This won't be used to fill up a 5 gallon potable water supply. But it is very portable, (there are smaller ones, yeah I know). There are ones that might be 'better'. But It is a good start, and I'm happy with it. Purchasing for a second bag -
customer_reviews.author: mark Olsen

customer_reviews.title: Insure Safe Water
customer_reviews.text: Who doesn't need one of these??? With water contamination occurring at alarming rates in communities, this is a quick backup for the questionable time when the local leaders tell you that your water is safe to drink while it is coming out brown out of your faucet! Right? While I did not intend for this to be a water filtrations system for home use, it is good insurance. I am looking forward to taking this on hikes, which is why I purchased it.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Be Prepared for who knows what!!
customer_reviews.text: This is great for good clean water. You never know when this will come in handy. I’ve used this hiking and when under water advisory before. With all the craziness going on in the world, I would definitely keep one or a few of these stocked in your emergency kit. I keep one in the car emergency kit as well as my first aid kit. Overall this is a great buy.
customer_reviews.author: K n M

customer_reviews.title: City &town water system can be cut off but not this!
customer_reviews.text: It has filter inside you can see it from the bottom portion of straw. I haven't tested it outside at a lake or river or with rain water and hopefully I never need to 🙄 But if ever need to I have a way to be able to drink some clean water in a dire emergency 👍 Water is life without it you die fast. 5 P's (PROPER,PREPARATION, PREVENT, POOR PERFORMANCE) 👌
customer_reviews.author: Zoease1

customer_reviews.title: Quench Your Thirst
customer_reviews.text: This a must have for any camper or bug out bag or if you just want to ensure the safety of the Aqua you are consuming. Money well spent. Your only regret will be not making this purchase as it filters 1000 gallons of water. This could be a life saver so it’s a no brainer... invest in yourself by caring for your. Health is wealth.
customer_reviews.author: Tenacity Best

customer_reviews.title: Great product and company, live up to the name!
customer_reviews.text: I took this unit on a couple of camping and fishing trips and fortunately I did not have to use it in an emergency. I would however use it just to show off the crazy capability of such a simple looking device. As other's have said yes it does take a little bit of lung power to get the water up through the straw, but it is handy, light, and worth the price to have in case of an emergency.
customer_reviews.author: Jamison

customer_reviews.title: Not puking today
customer_reviews.text: So far so good. Have not had the struggles others are having. The suction part is no where in comparable to sipping out of a straw, but I have owned other life straws and the power it takes to drink from these are the same. No one has gotten sick. We have used in the lake and in some streams. A lot lighter than carrying a gallon of water.
customer_reviews.author: Dee

customer_reviews.title: Hope it works. Hopefully I'll never find out.
customer_reviews.text: I am giving 5 stars because I could suck up water out of a scum pond if I wanted at some point in the future. I don't know how or why I would be in the situation to have to need this thing but happy to know it is there if I do. Zombie apocalypse, government shutdown and anarchy, terrorist takeover, being forced to drink Flint Michigan water, etc... Till then it will sit in the wrapper collecting dust. Or maybe I should buy a second one to test and do a taste test comparison from dirty pond scum water straight from the source vs this thing ';)
customer_reviews.author: C. Hogue

customer_reviews.title: Must have in your Doomsday kit.
customer_reviews.text: I've been holding off on these for a while, mainly due to my wife telling me that the world will not fall apart. Thanks to COVID-19, I am able to prove her wrong! These straws have an amazing shelf life and are truly "break glass in emergency". But I also carry them with me when I go on long hikes and camping. Because you never know! I don't buy insurance because I plan on getting into an accident. I buy it because I might. And a few dollars isn't too much to spend on clean water insurance.
customer_reviews.author: A.C.

customer_reviews.title: How to NOT get sick.
customer_reviews.text: Since I bought this product specifically for use in an emergency I haven't used it yet. It appears to be everything they've said it is. But it is now something that just gets put in whichever purse I'm using that day. Having had both "beaver fever and c-dif I can tell you if this product works as promised then I would have paid 10 times what they charged.
customer_reviews.author: Brenda Gregg

customer_reviews.title: I’m not crazy
customer_reviews.text: And for $10 bucks, you’d have to be crazy not to get a few. It’s a time tested and proven design. It’s simple, weighs almost nothing. Fits virtually anywhere. And it just might save your life. If those aren’t good enough reasons for you, I’m guessing you never leave your house. I have them stuck everywhere-each of my packs, my truck, my cars, even a couple just lying around the house. I highly recommend Thanks for reading
customer_reviews.author: MooseTop Contributor: Camping

customer_reviews.title: Developed Mold.  Make sure u air dry uncapped.
customer_reviews.text: I loved this straw. Unfortunately I hadn’t noticed the fine print that it needed to be aired out to dry after use. I was using regularly to filter water. After use I just blew out water and closed caps. Somehow I missed the memo of leaving caps open to air dry. So- taste of water was altered after 1 day of not using- and mold had began to develop. Only giving 2 stars because I wish the directions were more obvious. Also- when I purchased about a month ago- it was only 11.99 - it is now 17.99. So- repurchasing is out of the question.
customer_reviews.author: jps

customer_reviews.title: Makes swampwater taste amazing
customer_reviews.text: Hiking on the PCT we brought a Steripen for main use and a Lifestraw for backup. Really glad we made this decision. Hiking in drought conditions, often the only water sources we had were not much more than murky puddles. Although our Steripen worked fine, it doesn't do anything for filtering out the muck and organic material. Used our Lifestraw to drink the swamp-like water, and it tasted amazing. We'd fill up our water bottles with the muddy water and drink out of them using the steripen. Just watch out, it takes some perseverance to get it working the first time. Make sure to test it out at home before you really need it.
customer_reviews.author: S. Hill

customer_reviews.title: Affordability
customer_reviews.text: Affordability. This truly you need in a bug out bag. If you go camping buy a river this will save you from getting parasites that are in the river. I love how perfect it purifies things. I bought a few for my family members to. I recommend it to anyone who wants to Have it on hand for emergencies whether it’s keeping your car in your purse or in your house.
customer_reviews.author: glenda

customer_reviews.title: "I'm not dead yet!"
customer_reviews.text: Pretty great device. I've taken a sip from many a questionable water source through this thing and have never gotten sick. It's a little inconvenient to actually have to get down on your hands and knees to take a drink (unless you have another container to put the water in), but having a LifeStraw around while camping is very comforting. It's also very lightweight. Hope that's helpful.
customer_reviews.author: Solumadur

customer_reviews.title: Perfect back-up & emergency water solution. Looks as shown & described online
customer_reviews.text: Lightweight & compact for travel back-up system & emergency & earthquake pack. We have another system for daily & routine travel use, but these are the perfect, compact, packable, lightweight solution. I haven't tested it on hardcore or really murky waters, but reading other comments, I will follow their recommendations. I like that this solution doesn't require batteries, pumps, separate containers or waiting time, so this will be the best solution for when we need a quick filter in place of our water pumping system. I think it will be perfect as part of an emergency kit for any hikes away from base camp or as a back-up solution in case there are problems with the water pump.
customer_reviews.author: Sandy S.

customer_reviews.title: Prop 65 product
customer_reviews.text: Warning prop 65 warning product. Was really looking forward to this product until it came labeled can cause cancer and birth defects. Wish I would have known before ordering. Returning
customer_reviews.author: ShopGirl

customer_reviews.title: Haven’t had to use but I’d rather have it and not need it.
customer_reviews.text: We bought these for our hurricane kits. Most of the press and reviews are positive so I’ll stick with that. I haven’t had to use it fortunately, and I don’t really feel like testing it just because I can. We bought two as a redundancy and feel better about our emergency water situation because of them. I’d couple these with purification tablets just to be extra safe. You can only carry so much water, but these are very portable. The more I think about it, I may buy a pump one as well because I don’t look forward to constantly spitting filtered water in a bowl for the dogs in an emergency. That’s a joke. Kind of.
customer_reviews.author: Josh

customer_reviews.title: A few minor things but overall a great product
customer_reviews.text: It's almost perfect for a one step filter. My only complaint is when using it with a glass/bottle the dye was coming off and turning the water blue. It's good for use in flowing fresh water out in nature, not so much for removing bacteria from poor quality city/well water. It's hard to get the water flowing at first but that's to be expected. Once you initially get the water going it's easy from there. Drying is extremely difficult and takes lots of shaking over many, many days.
customer_reviews.author: Midlife Cooking

customer_reviews.title: Life saving, worth every penny.
customer_reviews.text: My brother and I kayaked in 100+ degree weather for three days. We originally had two Sawyer mini filters and 6 gallons of water between us. Our plan was to refill our water bladders with the sawyers but on the end of day two both filters failed. We were able to flush them and get them to work again when we got home but in the heat of the moment they failed us. I had purchased two of these and they didn't let us down. We stayed hydrated and I've since bought two spares as backups and switched to the platypus filter system. I highly recommend having multiple ways to access clean water.
customer_reviews.author: Ashton

customer_reviews.title: Wouldn't go on a hike without one
customer_reviews.text: I carry one in my pack when I'm on a hike. i carry my water with me but you never know. Even though i had plenty of water, I tried this on a recent hike and I couldn't believe how good the water tasted. My daughter and one of her friends also tried it and they thought it was great.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Value, Brand, compact, easy to use, affordable
customer_reviews.text: What can I say, it’s a life straw intended for emergencies ! I haven’t used the couple I purchased but living in South Florida with hurricanes, Everglades, boating , hiking, camping getting stranded is always a possibility . You’ll never know when you need it and if you don’t have you’ll wish you did ! Just get a few, there small ,light weight, easy to store and in any emergency where you’ll need water and can’t get any these are worth there weight and price.
customer_reviews.author: BKP830

customer_reviews.title: Trusted by the red cross
customer_reviews.text: Now I have NOT used these extensively over the years as you may see from hardcore campers and some 3rd world regions might, however I have used various versions of the life straw including knock-offs and all seem to do the same thing by filtering bacteria via the hollow tube membranes inside the plastic sleeve....I seem to gravitate to the life straw brand even though it's $3-$5 more expensive than the knock offs due to confidence in the brand and the red Cross backing it
customer_reviews.author: Drew

customer_reviews.title: Use limited to bottle attachment or directly from water source
customer_reviews.text: This filter may be fine in an emergency or if you have a commercial water/soda bottle or one that fits the filter to attach it to. However, it did not meet our purpose for an extended camping trip. Our goal was to quickly filter 2-4 liters of water to refill bladders, water bottles and cook. Also, we did not want to contaminate our primary water bottles. We returned this item and purchased the Katadyn Befree Replacement Cartridge and the Hydrapak Seeker 3 liter bag. Cost a bit more, but it filters large amount of water quickly and prevents cross contamination of water bottles and bladders.
customer_reviews.author: blessedw2

customer_reviews.title: okay for an emergency but,..
customer_reviews.text: the straw couldn't be simpler to use but considering the effort it took to use the plunger and the quantity of water filtered it isn't something i'd want to use on a regular basis, emergencies yes otherwise not so much. that's why i ended up getting something a little different for hiking. there is nothing wrong with this at all just as said more of an emergency device not so much if you know you will need to filter water.
customer_reviews.author: MikenzCO

customer_reviews.title: I ordered this because it said it was a bundle ...
customer_reviews.text: I ordered this because it said it was a bundle of 2 and I just received it and it was only one. If I only wanted one I would have purchased a 1 pack for the $9.99 and not the $19.99
customer_reviews.author: Lana M.

customer_reviews.title: Worked like advertise
customer_reviews.text: I bought this set of 3. I kept one for myself, one as a gift and one to try it out and see how well it worked. From my experience it works like its supposed to but as an emergency only. I would not want to use this on regular camping trips as it is hard to suck up the water from it unless you are using a bottle water and forcing water into the straw. But it does make water safer and in an emergency some water is better than no water even if its hard to suck up the water. Definitely something you want for your camping, hiking or emergency backpack.
customer_reviews.author: Jose Zambrano

customer_reviews.title: 3 days, still has residual water inside
customer_reviews.text: The water came out had a plastic taste to it which really isn't that bad if you're desperately in need of water. The thing that bothers me is that it has been left out to dry for 3 days now and despite having blown water out of it on several occasions, there still seems to be water trapped inside. This after having made sure both ends were open, blowing till nothing else comes out, and leaving the straw both upright AND on its side to drain. Maybe I've done something wrong, but I don't feel comfortable using this again in the future.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Worked for only 2 liters of water
customer_reviews.text: This was a complete rip off. I took it into the wilderness 3 weeks ago and and and it clogged/stopped working after only 2 liters of use. The water was from a clear steams and ponds only.
customer_reviews.author: Mark Gallardo

customer_reviews.title: Quenching!
customer_reviews.text: For those looking for a real review, from a real customer, I can tell you right now that this really works. Every couple of years I go on a 5 day wilderness trip with my friends and as you may have guessed we were separated. Water was no issue once I used this straw. It's a great psychological boost because it's one MAJOR survival element you can cross off the list. Thank you for such a great product!
customer_reviews.author: Robert Dandino

customer_reviews.title: Needed emergency gear!
customer_reviews.text: This order was a spare. We have a larger set-up for filtration, but wanted individual gear for whatever. LifeStraw has a good rating, is cost effective, and is highly portable for hikes or mobile activities. We keep extras in our vehicles, go-bags, and range bags as they don't spoil.
customer_reviews.author: gutthans

customer_reviews.title: Extremely Lightweight and Works Effectively
customer_reviews.text: I was skeptical at first to how lightweight and how well this product would function. Very surprised as this weighs next to nothing when adding it to my backpack and extremely easy to use and clean. I also have a sawyer system and this works just as well. The only downside is it's a little bit longer than I expected, but virtually takes up no room. The taste of water is good and is so helpful to use in case of emergency or for backpacking.
customer_reviews.author: Blue

customer_reviews.title: Pretty good, works as advertised
customer_reviews.text: When I decided to parajump into Upper Bolivian to track the spotted Emu colony, this was my first requirement. While it doesn’t necessarily take away the taste I have reasonably certainty that I will be able to live on the small droplets if water that collect in the emu tracks from the morning dew
customer_reviews.author: D. S. Reesman

customer_reviews.title: LIfeStraw is a LifeSaver
customer_reviews.text: This is my second LifeStraw that I have used. It is small enough to go into your backpack or day bag. Definitely a plus for going to small town in the U.S. and out of the country where you are not sure about where that water source is coming from. Better safe than sorry. Open your water bottle and insert your LifeStraw. No reason to take a chance on losing out on days because you are sick in so many unpleasant ways.
customer_reviews.author: Brandy

customer_reviews.title: Good for camping , travel, or survival kit
customer_reviews.text: I bought this for emergencies, but may never use it since I have bottled water on hand, but who knows what may happen so I really recommend this. It's small and should fit easily into anyone's kit. If you have several people to protect, buy one for each person unless you don't mind sharing germs. It doesn't work forever either, so having one for each person will also help them last longer than if one is shared by all.
customer_reviews.author: Therese Shellabarger

customer_reviews.title: I use this around the world
customer_reviews.text: I have been using Life Straws for a number of years. I travel to many places with questionable drinking water. Even some hotels/airbnbs/tent camps which say they have potable water can have sketchy water systems. I screw a water "fill bag" onto the straw and push the water through the straw into water glasses.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Purchased premium pack and per frequently asked questions it said ...
customer_reviews.text: Purchased premium pack and per frequently asked questions it said it brought 2. I only received one. There was a cheaper option had I known it was only one I would have went with the other.
customer_reviews.author: Luis Rivera

customer_reviews.title: Don’t leave home without it!
customer_reviews.text: These things are invaluable. I keep them in my car, my travel trailer, and my ATVs just in case. They are so light, you should also put one in your backpack if you hike. Order the case for it too - will keep the straw protected. Nice to know I will always be able to get water from any water source, if needed. I remember the days of using the drop in tablets, but they take too long to purify. Will never be w/o these straws.
customer_reviews.author: Just Jodi

customer_reviews.title: Saved my life!
customer_reviews.text: I love this and fully Believe it saved my life when my gravity filter failed me! Won’t ever go packing with out it!
customer_reviews.author: robert dugdale

customer_reviews.title: Great for emergency preparedness, hiking, etc.
customer_reviews.text: I have not needed to use it yet. I have it ready in my bug out bag. It’s well built, compact, and very light weight to carry. My friend bought the same one and uses it regularly on long hikes. He said it filters very well and the water taste like bottled water after you prime it and spit out first sip or two. He did tell me to make sure when you use it to blow out through the straw and then let it dry a little before replacing the to prevent mold or mildew.
customer_reviews.author: Eric

customer_reviews.title: I have used it if all kinds of water and no matter the color of the water it tastes like pure water
customer_reviews.text: This is a must buy! It has really helped me feel safer when I got hiking. Knowing that if I potential got lost or stuck for a few days and all I needed to do was find a water source to survive brings so much comfort to me. I have used it if all kinds of water and no matter the color of the water it tastes like pure water!!
customer_reviews.author: Yvette B.

customer_reviews.title: Must need for a survival bag
customer_reviews.text: This product is amazing. I keep mine for emergencies but I have tried one before. It is a little larger than you would expect but it still fits well in any back pack or emergency kit. Unfortunitely whatever water youre using will keep its flavor but since this is used for emergencies I dont think youll be caring about the taste of the water as long as its filtered. Easy to use and the packaging it comes in has instructions/uses.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Saved our backpacking trip
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this in 2013 and have almost always included it in my hiking bag, but have never needed to use it until a trip a few days ago when our regular water filter failed. So after 6 years of carrying this around, forgetting about it, and not even having any instructions for it, we were able to easily drink out of the lake and creek with this and complete our backpacking trip which otherwise would have been a nightmare! We just had narrow mouth Nalgene bottles but if you had the wide mouth ones, you could easily scoop up dirty water and then use the life straw in the bottle if you needed a more portable source.
customer_reviews.author: Brian

customer_reviews.title: Should be a part of anyone's emergency kit - this is our 2nd one.
customer_reviews.text: This is the 2nd LifeStraw we own. While we can't comment on the specifications for it, we're going by those specs vs. the price, and what it's for. It's part of our emergency kit, and hopefully we'll never have to use it. But to be able to safely filter 1000 liters of water in an emergency, and at this price vs. size, it's an outstanding option for emergencies.
customer_reviews.author: Grits

customer_reviews.title: Not sure how this is even useful
customer_reviews.text: Small unit, but I exchanged for a Sawyer mini because it can go inline with my hydration pack. I imagine it would take a long time to filter water with this unit and you would need a larger mouth water bottle.
customer_reviews.author: Rachel

customer_reviews.title: As advertised.
customer_reviews.text: I cant give these thing a full review yet cause they are not being used right away, they are packaged nicely and have the user information on the package including it meets EPA drinking water standards.. Why would the review include "Flavor" ?? They aren't supposed to have any. My rating is based more on the fact they have been around a while.
customer_reviews.author: M.

customer_reviews.title: Rating for build, quality, and potential.
customer_reviews.text: We bought these prior to hurricane Irma since we weren’t sure how the water supply would be. Thank God we never had to use them; ergo, I can’t review it’s effectiveness. However, the build and quality of the LifeStraw is almost perfect. There were a few rough edges on the mouth piece, but that’s not going to stop me in an emergency. It has a potential to work and I would feel much more comfortable drinking through it than just drinking out of unknown water sources. I may have to buy more just to keep in all our travel bags. Who knows when the next big one hits?
customer_reviews.author: Scorpion E

customer_reviews.title: Slurp away!
customer_reviews.text: So I actually own 6 or 7 of these (I’ve lost count). They are handy and effective, and just plain novel when you come to a mountain stream, a lake, or even a puddle! If you keep a small cup with you it makes it easier to filter out of, instead of laying on your belly. Also good for melting snow. They are lightweight and compact to go in your backpack, bike bag, dry bag, automobile, etc. Provide a nice peace of mind on excursions, when you’re not worried about conserving or running out of water.
customer_reviews.author: Greg jacobs

customer_reviews.title: Critical piece of gear!
customer_reviews.text: There's not much to say if you don't have a good water filter. Without one, you take the risk of dysentery (or worse), leaving you so sick and quickly dehydrating and putting you back at square one where you took a chance and got bad water. Not smart! The Lifestraw is your lifeline in the event of an emergency. It will filter out all the nasty crud that can make you sick or even kill you. No joke, my friend. It doesn't take up any room and is ready and easy to use. Just add water. :)
customer_reviews.author: D. Meledie Knopf

customer_reviews.title: Open package
customer_reviews.text: Looked like a good filter. However the factory package was opened and Amazon just put it in a clear bag and shipped it. I returned it since I wasn’t sure if it had been used.
customer_reviews.author: J

customer_reviews.title: Great for Hiking
customer_reviews.text: Fantastic, and an absolute lifesaver. This product was everything I was hoping for and more! I'm an avid hiker, and now that I have a lifestraw I only carry water with me if there are no streams, lakes, etc. nearby the trails I'm on! Light, convenient, and easy to use! I would suggest however to BRING A CUP, or something else to drink out of with the water you scoop out of the river. It is very difficult to bend over the water and create enough suction to actually get water flowing. But if you have a small cup or container its a breeze! I cant wait to use this for many years to come!
customer_reviews.author: Spencer and Sharene

customer_reviews.title: Quality filtration straws...
customer_reviews.text: They are quality filtration straws. Took Concord grape juice and removed the juice and colors approx 99% first filtration- has a smell of grape juice without any flavor and virtually no color- same with iced tea. Note you must blow hard to clean the straw back out after each use but it is necessary ...A tad on the bulky side but also very effective...
customer_reviews.author: Colle Sefton

customer_reviews.title: LifeStraw is AMAZING!
customer_reviews.text: I bought this for my son for when he hikes. I bought a LifeStraw bottle for an overseas trip to visit a friend because I have a very sensitive GI tract and wanted to only drink filtered water and it worked perfectly! So when my son started hiking with his buddies, I knew I wanted him to carry this with him as a just in case...
customer_reviews.author: Daytona675

product_meta.title: LifeStraw Personal Water Filter for Hiking, Camping, Travel, and Emergency Preparedness
feature_bullets: Award-winning LifeStraw water filter is a must-carry tool for hiking, camping, travel, and emergencies; no disaster kit is complete without it
Filters up to 1,000 gallons (4,000 liters) of contaminated water without iodine, chlorine, or other chemicals; does not require batteries and has no moving parts
Removes minimum 99.9999% of waterborne bacteria, 99.9% of waterborne protozoan parasites, and filters to 0.2 microns; surpasses EPA filter standards
An alternative to iodine tablets and bulky purifiers, it weighs 2oz for ultralight portability, and has a high flow rate for drinking from the source
Comes in a sealed bag, perfect for storing in a bugout bag or other prepper gear supply kit; measures 9 x 1 x 1 inches.BPA Free materials

specifications.Customer Reviews: /** Fix for UDP-1061. Average customer reviews has a small extra line on hover* https://omni-grok.amazon.com/xref/src/appgroup/websiteTemplates/retail/SoftlinesDetailPageAssets/udp-intl-lock/src/legacy.css?indexName=WebsiteTemplates#40*/.noUnderline a:hover {text-decoration: none;}
